title: Reducing Hallucinations of Medical Multimodal Large Language Models with Visual Retrieval-Augmented Generation
author: Yun-Wei Chu (NEC Laboratories America), Kai Zhang (Purdue University), Christopher Malon (NEC Laboratories America), Martin Renqiang Min (NEC Laboratories America), ...
relevance_why: The methodologies for enhancing multimodal understanding could inform approaches in audio-visual generation and retrieval tasks in Haohe Liu's work on audio and music processing.
background: This paper focuses on improving the accuracy of medical report generation from images by integrating visual and textual data to reduce inaccuracies, known as hallucinations.
contribution: This work introduces a Visual Retrieval-Augmented Generation (V-RAG) framework to mitigate hallucinations in medical reports, achieving higher accuracy in entity recognition.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods primarily relied on text-only retrieval, which inadequately addressed the complexity of visual data.
technical_comparison.novelty: This research enhances the model's performance by incorporating both visual and textual retrievals, enabling a more comprehensive understanding of the medical context.

key_innovation: The integration of visual data alongside textual information for retrieval significantly improves the model’s ability to generate accurate medical reports.
real_world_impact: Improved accuracy in medical report generation can enhance clinical decision-making and patient outcomes, directly impacting healthcare quality.
limitations: No specific limitations explicitly mentioned by the authors.

new_terms.hallucination: **Hallucination** refers to the phenomenon where models generate incorrect or nonsensical outputs that are not grounded in the input data, a critical issue in healthcare applications.
new_terms.Visual Retrieval-Augmented Generation (V: **Visual Retrieval-Augmented Generation (V-RAG)** is a new framework that combines retrieval of relevant visual data and text to improve generative tasks, particularly in multimodal contexts.
